title: 112_s3404
content: The Act may be cited as the "Department of Energy Reorganization Act of 2012". Congress finds that Americans are paying more for energy, consolidating energy functions in one agency would improve policy coherence, the Department of Energy's mission is to ensure energy security, it is the main source for energy data, the Energy Information Administration can best address national energy needs, and fossil-fuel production on Federal land is declining. The Secretary of the Interior restricts access to domestic energy, focuses on conservation over energy needs, and makes decisions that hinder economic growth and fail to meet energy needs in the United States. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term ``Department'' means the Department of Energy. The term ``Secretary'' means the Secretary of Energy. SEC. 4. OFFICE OF FEDERAL ENERGY PRODUCTION. The Office of Federal Energy Production is established within the Department, headed by a Director appointed by the Secretary. Functions from various bureaus related to oil, gas, and renewable energy production are transferred to the Director. The Department establishes the Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement, headed by a Director appointed by the Secretary. All relevant functions related to safety and environmental enforcement are transferred to the Director. Additionally, the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management is also established. SEC. 6. BUREAU OF OCEAN ENERGY MANAGEMENT. The Bureau is established within the Department, headed by a Director appointed by the Secretary. All functions related to ocean energy management are transferred to the Director. Section 18 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to require the Secretary of Energy to certify that energy programs will meet national needs for a 5-year period. The Secretary can modify or reject programs and determine the need for oil from foreign sources. The Secretary of Energy must certify that energy programs will meet national needs for a 5-year period. If oil is needed from foreign sources other than Canada and Mexico, additional lease sales in additional areas must be included in the program. Private entities can provide a notice of interest to lease and produce oil in areas not prohibited by a moratorium, leading to modifications in the plan for the next year. SEC. 8 amends the Mineral Leasing Act to authorize funds for research and requires the Secretary of Energy to post revenue and production data online. SEC. 9 exempts the Department of Energy from certain legal acts. SEC. 10 addresses the transfer and allocations of appropriations and personnel. SEC. 10 addresses the transfer and allocation of personnel, assets, liabilities, contracts, and unexpended funds to the Secretary for appropriate use. Unexpended funds must be used for their original purposes, and specific positions designated by statute or reorganization plan are transferred with their personnel. Compensation for positions at certain levels under the Executive Schedule on the effective date of this Act will be subject to section 3103 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 11. EFFECT ON PERSONNEL. The transfer of personnel under this Act shall not result in separation or reduction in grade or compensation for one year. Employees appointed to new positions with comparable duties shall maintain their previous compensation level. Reemployment rights are also protected. Reemployment rights acquired under any provision of law may be exercised by an employee transferred to the Department within the latter of a 120-day period from the effective date of the Act or a 2-year period from acquiring the rights, at the employee's request. SEC. 12. AGENCY TERMINATIONS. Whenever all functions of an agency, commission, or body are terminated or transferred by this Act, the agency shall terminate along with all positions and offices authorized by law or receiving compensation at specified rates. SEC. 13. INCIDENTAL TRANSFERS. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Secretary, will determine necessary transfers of functions, personnel, assets, liabilities, contracts, and funds related to agencies affected by this Act. SEC. 14. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. All orders, rules, permits, contracts, licenses, and privileges issued by authorized officials or courts shall remain in effect until modified or revoked by law. Pending Proceedings: This Act will not impact any ongoing proceedings, applications for licenses, permits, certificates, or financial assistance that are pending before departments, agencies, or commissions whose functions are being transferred by this Act. These proceedings and applications will continue if they relate to functions transferred by this Act. Orders issued in ongoing proceedings will remain in effect until modified, terminated, superseded, or revoked by authorized officials, a court, or operation of law. The Act allows for the modification or discontinuation of ongoing proceedings under the same terms and conditions. The Secretary may establish regulations for the transfer of these proceedings to the Department. Any suits initiated before the Act's effective date will continue unaffected, with proceedings, appeals, and judgments proceeding as if the Act had not been enacted. No ongoing suits will be affected by the enactment of the Act, whether involving officers, departments, or agencies. Any proceedings initiated before the Act's effective date will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. Any ongoing suits involving departments, agencies, or officers before the Act's effective date will continue with the Secretary or other official if any functions are transferred under the Act. SEC. 15. REFERENCE. Functions transferred by this Act will now be under the Secretary or other official of the Department. SEC. 16. PRESIDENTIAL AUTHORITY. The President's functions and authority remain unaffected by this Act. SEC. 17. TRANSITION. SEC. 17. TRANSITION. The Secretary may utilize personnel from other departments to facilitate the transfer of functions under this Act.
